'Too scared to speak'

07/11/2013

With speech difficulties hitting popular media, an anonymous York student reveals to Emily Henderson what it is like to live life with a stammer

Image by

By undefined undefined

The last episode of 'Educating Yorkshire' was a particularly touching one. It portrayed the story of a young adult who, as a result of a terrible stammer, was at the point of muteness. For those of us for whom speech comes easily, it is often difficult to understand the lack of control the sufferers feel, and the day to day strain it can place upon an individual. In light of this, I was able to interview a student at the University, to discuss how their speech problems have affected their education. The student, who wishes to remain anonymous, first started to notice his stutter at the age of seven. "If ever in my class I raised my hand to speak and began a little bit of nervous stammering, my teacher would shout at me saying 'don't stutter'. Although it wasn't a problem at first, the more she did it, the more I stuttered." He explains that whilst her methods were an attempt to help him, aiming to stop his stuttering before it truly started, it ultimately created a "sense of fear". As a result, our student soon found that this created even more difficulties. Due to his young age, he developed a facial tick as a means of expressing his anger, through scrunching his face and blinking heavily. The tick ultimately became so noticeable that his parents picked up on the issue, and began to think that the tick was the actual cause of his speech difficulties, rather than the fear of a teacher. Because of this, he became "more shy", and resorted to hiding away rather than risking the "fear and anger" that came with talking.
Who would want to go through life relying on someone to talk for you?
The recent episode of 'Educating Yorkshire' was therefore very significant for the student, evoking great sympathy within him. "Although my stutter wasn't as severe as Musharaf's, there were elements where there were similarities. It was things such as the way in which people interact with you, by finishing your sentences. They often think that they are helping, but it tends to feel too overly sympathetic." He went on to state that this often resulted in more stress being placed upon him. If ever someone made the wrong point for him, he would be forced to correct his own statement, adding to the mounting pressure. The result was a strong sense of powerlessness and frustration. "Who would want to go through life relying on someone to talk for you?" This frustration was also seen with Musharaf in the episode. He explained to the viewers that his stammer felt like someone was keeping his "mouth closed", "smashing" his "head with a hammer", causing him to feel like an "idiot". For our student, however, this was a little different. "It was more that the words were being forced back into me. I couldn't feel stupid necessarily, because I tended to shy away from everything and not speak in class. My fear of stuttering meant that I tended not to even try." Despite noticing clear similarities between himself and Musharaf, the student also pointed out significant differences between their experiences, most notably the difference between state and private schools. Educating Yorkshire is based within a state school, whilst our student attended a private school. The primary distinction, he states, is class size, with private education groups tending to be much smaller. Surprisingly though, our student found this to be a negative thing. "It made me feel like I was the centre of attention and that I couldn't just be lost in a crowd".
his teachers also provided very little support, adopting a 'corporal punishment element'
He explains that his teachers also provided very little support, adopting a "corporal punishment element" to their teachings. "They believed that being strict would solve any issues. Rather than realising my stutter, they treated me as though I was just another shy child that didn't want to talk. But it was that I was too scared to talk because of my stammer." Instead, he states, his teachers believed it could be cured with forced interaction, and, when this did not work, he was greeted with shouting. "It got to the point where, with my stutter, I wanted to have the ability to be ignored, due to a fear that any stammering would just entice shouting. With a small class of ten though, this could not be the case." Yet problems, our student states, were not restricted to the teachers. 'Educating Yorkshire' highlighted bulling, something that, sadly, our student experienced firsthand. "In secondary school the years above me were particularly cruel. I remember one terrible time where I was put in a bin as a result of stuttering whilst trying to explain myself. From day to day I would be shoved and pushed over. I think people thought that I was trying to mock them." Difficulties also arose within the education system, both for Musharaf and our student. The episode saw Musharaf attempting to complete his speaking exam, a major part of his English GCSE. It was, as his English teacher explained, 20% of his exam that he could not access the marks to. For our student however, the difficulties were felt across the entire curriculum. The biggest problem he faced was that he "would not interact at all in lessons", meaning, as a result, he felt he did not understand certain subjects, being too afraid to ask questions. "I was too scared to speak, leaving me with unanswered and unspoken questions. It led to significant gaps in my knowledge."
some people see it as attention seeking
The biggest challenge though, was learning a new language. For all of us, the ability of picking up an accent is difficult, yet with a stutter, this can be disastrous for your grades. "Any form of stuttering seems to be hesitation, which is seen as a result of not knowing the exam or not having revised properly. The issue was with assessments, because teachers have to base so much on how confidently we speak, meaning that a stammer appears to have a lack of confidence." What may be surprising to some though, is the level of difficulty that some words have over others. 'Educating Yorkshire' highlighted this, showing how some words were much easier for Musharaf to say. Because of this, our student claims, some people have tended to view stammers as "fake". "Some people see it as attention seeking, due to a lack of understanding about the complete loss of control people have when they stammer. For those who can talk so easily, it is difficult to understand the level a stammer can prevent someone from speaking." Despite this, both Musharaf and our student have found important coping methods that help to improve their stammer. For Musharaf, this was tapping his leg whilst speaking. Whilst some saw this as a sign of anger or impatience, our student states that it was more a "means of creating a rhythm to help him to speak. I did a similar thing where I tapped out syllables, which allowed me to play with a word before I said something. At first, I thought that the faster I spoke, the easier and quicker it would be to get my words out, but in reality this made it so much harder for me and would cause me to trip over myself." Music was also a key factor in aiding Musharaf's speech, something which, to someone without a stammer, may seem difficult to comprehend, as it is difficult to see how music can help, rather than confuse the speaker. For our student though, it is an important aid. "It means that you're not aware of yourself slipping up, so it takes away any fear. It drowns everything out to the point where you're unaware you're speaking." Music was also key to another piece of media that portrayed someone with a stammer, this being 'The King's Speech'. For our student, however, this provoked a very different reaction to that of 'Educating Yorkshire'. "It was odd to watch, simply because of the way in which Colin Firth chose to act as though every time he stuttered, he was going to be sick. Although, as there is no universal stammer between people, this was an important visual representation, as well as verbal." Luckily our student was able to develop his own coping method for his stammer. "If I found myself about to stutter I would stop and take a breath and on the exhale I would finish the sentence in one smooth go. It created a sense of calmness, overriding the panic surrounding the stammer." Although one can only touch the surface of what it is to have a stammer, the recent episode of 'Educating Yorkshire' offered a glimpse into the lives of those who struggle on a day to day basis. It is clear that one cannot take for granted the ease of speaking, as the impact for those who cannot can be huge. The light that recent media has placed upon stammers, will, hopefully, help to aid those who do suffer, not to suffer in silence. Featured image credited to SimonDeanMedia
